quick_answer.what: Cerro Azul is an active stratovolcano in central Chile, rising to 3,788 m (12,428 ft), at the southern end of the Descabezado Grande-Cerro Azul eruptive system.
quick_answer.status: Active — last erupted in 1967 from the Quizapu flank vent. The 1932 eruption from Quizapu was one of the largest explosive eruptions of the 20th century.
quick_answer.famous_for: The Quizapu vent on its northern flank, which produced one of the world's largest 20th-century eruptions in April 1932, ejecting an estimated 9.5 cubic kilometers of dacitic tephra (VEI 5).
quick_answer.danger_level: Moderate — the volcano is remote and sparsely populated in its immediate vicinity, but a repeat of the 1932-scale eruption would deposit ash across central Chile and Argentina.

overview.content: Cerro Azul is an active stratovolcano in the Maule Region of central Chile, rising to 3,788 m (12,428 ft) at the southern end of the Descabezado Grande-Cerro Azul eruptive system. While the name Cerro Azul ('Blue Hill') is unremarkable, the volcano hosts one of the most significant volcanic vents in the Americas: Quizapu, a flank crater on the northern slope that produced one of the largest explosive eruptions of the 20th century in April 1932. That eruption — rated VEI 5 — ejected an estimated 9.5 km3 of dacitic tephra, creating a crater 600-700 m wide and 150 m deep, and depositing ash across a vast area of Chile and Argentina. Despite its magnitude, the 1932 Quizapu eruption remains one of the least known major volcanic events of the 20th century, overshadowed in public awareness by eruptions at more famous volcanoes. Cerro Azul's steep-sided edifice features a 500-m-wide summit crater open to the north, with the Quizapu vent, La Resoloma scoria vents, and Los Hornitos cones on its western and southwestern flanks. All 11 recorded eruptions since 1846 have originated from the Quizapu vent rather than the summit crater. The volcano is part of the Ring of Fire, generated by subduction of the Nazca Plate beneath the South American Plate.

geology_and_formation.content: Cerro Azul is part of the Descabezado Grande-Cerro Azul volcanic complex in the Southern Andean Volcanic Arc. The main edifice is a steep-sided stratovolcano composed primarily of dacitic lavas and pyroclastic deposits, reflecting the high-silica, viscous magma compositions that drive explosive eruptions. The summit crater, 500 m wide and open to the north, represents a past explosive or collapse event. The most significant geological feature is the Quizapu vent on the northern flank, which formed during the first recorded eruption in 1846 with the emission of voluminous dacitic lava flows that traveled both east into the Estero Barroso valley and west into the Rio Blanquillo valley. Quizapu subsequently became the dominant eruptive center, producing all subsequent activity. The three basaltic-andesite La Resoloma scoria vents on the western flank and the two Los Hornitos scoria cones on the lower southwestern flank represent compositionally distinct, more mafic magma pathways. The dacitic composition of Quizapu's eruptions — similar to the magma that drives explosive eruptions at Mount Pinatubo and Mount St. Helens — explains the volcano's capacity for large-scale explosive events.

eruption_history_overview.content: The Smithsonian database records 11 eruptions at Cerro Azul, all from the Quizapu vent, spanning from November 1846 to August 1967. The eruption record shows an interesting pattern: effusive lava-flow activity from 1846 to 1853, a series of small explosive events in the early 20th century (1903-1914), then the cataclysmic VEI 5 explosion of 1932, followed by smaller events through 1967. The most significant event by far was the April 1932 eruption, which ejected 9.5 km3 of tephra — placing it among the largest eruptions of the 20th century. The transition from effusive to explosive activity at Quizapu reflects changes in the magmatic system's volatile content and eruption dynamics over the 86-year eruptive sequence.

subsections.title: The 1846-1853 Eruption — Birth of Quizapu
subsections.content: The first historically recorded eruption at Cerro Azul began on November 26, 1846, when the Quizapu vent opened on the northern flank. This eruption was predominantly effusive, producing voluminous dacitic lava flows that traveled in two directions: east into the Estero Barroso valley and west into the Rio Blanquillo valley. The eruption continued intermittently until 1853, rated VEI 2. The formation of Quizapu established the flank vent that would dominate all subsequent eruptive activity at Cerro Azul.

subsections.title: The 1932 Quizapu Eruption — One of the 20th Century's Largest
subsections.content: On April 10, 1932, the Quizapu vent erupted in a massive Plinian explosion that ranks as one of the largest volcanic eruptions of the 20th century. The eruption, rated VEI 5, ejected an estimated 9.5 km3 of dacitic tephra, creating the 600-700 m wide, 150 m deep Quizapu crater that remains the vent's most prominent feature. The eruption column rose to an estimated 27-30 km altitude, penetrating deep into the stratosphere. Ash fall was deposited across an enormous area of Chile and Argentina, with significant accumulations reported in Buenos Aires, approximately 1,500 km to the east. The eruption's remote location meant that direct casualties were minimal — a fortunate circumstance given the eruption's intensity. In terms of tephra volume, the 1932 Quizapu eruption was comparable to the 1902 eruption of Santa Maria in Guatemala (VEI 6, 8.5-10 km3) and exceeded the 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens (VEI 5, 1.2 km3) by a factor of nearly eight. Despite this, the eruption remains remarkably obscure in popular volcano awareness — a 'forgotten giant' of 20th-century volcanism. The eruption appears in the Smithsonian database as part of a longer episode spanning 1916-1932 that included precursory lava effusion before the climactic explosion.

subsections.title: The 1967 Eruption — Last Recorded Activity
subsections.content: The most recent eruption at Cerro Azul occurred on August 9, 1967, with a small explosive event (VEI 2) from the Quizapu vent. This was a minor event compared to the 1932 cataclysm, producing modest ash emissions. Since 1967, the volcano has been quiescent, though the ~58-year repose is well within the range of quiet intervals observed at similar Andean stratovolcanoes.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: Cerro Azul has been quiescent since the 1967 eruption. SERNAGEOMIN, Chile's national geological survey, monitors the volcano as part of its Southern Andean Volcanic Arc surveillance program, though monitoring infrastructure at this relatively remote site is less extensive than at more frequently active Chilean volcanoes like Villarrica or Copahue. The volcano's demonstrated capacity for VEI 5 eruptions — with the 1932 event serving as a stark reminder — means that any signs of renewed unrest at Quizapu would be taken extremely seriously. The remote location provides a natural buffer against casualties, but a repeat of the 1932 eruption would deposit ash across major agricultural regions and cities in central Chile and Argentina.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: The primary hazards from Cerro Azul include large explosive eruptions from the Quizapu vent (as demonstrated in 1932), dacitic lava flows, pyroclastic flows, and widespread ashfall. The 1932 eruption deposited ash as far as Buenos Aires (~1,500 km east), demonstrating the potential for trans-continental tephra dispersal. While the volcano's immediate surroundings are sparsely populated, a VEI 5 eruption would significantly impact aviation, agriculture, and air quality across central Chile and western Argentina. Lava flows from the Quizapu vent, as occurred in 1846-1853, could travel several kilometers down the Estero Barroso and Rio Blanquillo valleys. The dacitic magma composition means that dome-building and dome-collapse pyroclastic flows are also plausible hazard scenarios.

geography_and_physical_description.content: Cerro Azul is a steep-sided stratovolcano with a 500-m-wide summit crater open to the north, located in the rugged, sparsely populated Maule Region of central Chile at the border with Argentina. The Quizapu crater on the northern flank — 600-700 m wide and 150 m deep, formed during the 1932 eruption — is the volcano's most prominent feature. The La Resoloma scoria vents lie below the western flank, and the Los Hornitos cones occupy the lower southwestern slope. The volcano is the southern anchor of the Descabezado Grande-Cerro Azul system, with Descabezado Grande (3,953 m) located to the north. The surrounding landscape is characterized by high-altitude Andean terrain with limited vegetation at higher elevations and more productive agricultural zones in the valleys below.

cultural_significance.content: Despite hosting one of the largest volcanic eruptions of the 20th century, Cerro Azul remains remarkably little known outside volcanological circles. The 1932 Quizapu eruption occurred in a remote region during a period of political and economic turmoil in Chile, which limited both documentation and public attention. The eruption is nonetheless of major scientific significance: it demonstrated that seemingly quiescent flank vents can transition rapidly from effusive to explosive behavior, and the 9.5 km3 tephra deposit serves as a key reference for understanding large dacitic eruptions. In the local communities of the Maule Region, the eruption is remembered in oral history and local lore.

visiting_and_tourism.content: Cerro Azul is located in a remote area of the Chilean Andes with limited tourism infrastructure. Access requires travel through the Maule Region, typically via unpaved mountain roads. The volcano is not part of a national park, and organized tours are uncommon. Experienced mountaineers occasionally climb the peak, but the ascent is challenging and requires proper alpine equipment. The Quizapu crater can be observed from the northern approach. The region offers scenic Andean landscapes but lacks the tourism facilities found at more accessible Chilean volcanoes like Villarrica or Osorno.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Cerro Azul is part of the Descabezado Grande-Cerro Azul volcanic system, with Descabezado Grande (3,953 m) located to the north. Other nearby volcanoes in the Southern Andean Volcanic Arc include Planchon-Peteroa (3,977 m) and Maipo Caldera (5,323 m) to the north, and Copahue (2,953 m), Lonquimay (2,832 m), and Llaima (3,125 m) to the south.

etymology.content: Cerro Azul simply means 'Blue Hill' or 'Blue Mountain' in Spanish — a common toponym in Latin America applied to numerous peaks. The more distinctive name Quizapu, referring to the principal eruptive vent, is believed to derive from a Mapudungun (Mapuche language) word, though its precise meaning is not definitively established.

faqs.question: What was the 1932 Quizapu eruption?
faqs.answer: The April 1932 eruption from the Quizapu vent on Cerro Azul's northern flank was one of the largest volcanic eruptions of the 20th century, rated VEI 5. It ejected an estimated 9.5 km3 of dacitic tephra — nearly eight times the volume of the 1980 Mount St. Helens eruption. The eruption column reached 27-30 km altitude, and ash was deposited as far as Buenos Aires, 1,500 km away. The explosion created the Quizapu crater (600-700 m wide, 150 m deep). Despite its magnitude, casualties were minimal due to the volcano's remote location.

faqs.question: Is Cerro Azul still active?
faqs.answer: Yes, Cerro Azul is classified as an active stratovolcano. Its most recent eruption occurred in August 1967, a small explosive event (VEI 2) from the Quizapu vent. The 58-year repose since then is within normal ranges for Andean stratovolcanoes. The volcano's demonstrated capacity for VEI 5 eruptions, as shown by the catastrophic 1932 event, means it remains a significant long-term hazard. It is monitored by Chile's SERNAGEOMIN.

faqs.question: How big was the 1932 eruption compared to other eruptions?
faqs.answer: The 1932 Quizapu eruption (VEI 5, 9.5 km3 tephra) was one of the four or five largest eruptions of the 20th century. It was comparable in volume to the 1902 Santa Maria eruption (8.5-10 km3) and the 1991 Pinatubo eruption (~10 km3), both rated VEI 6. It was significantly larger than the 1980 Mount St. Helens eruption (1.2 km3). Only the 1912 Novarupta eruption (13 km3) clearly exceeded it in the 20th century.

faqs.question: Where is Cerro Azul volcano?
faqs.answer: Cerro Azul is located in the Maule Region of central Chile, in the southern Andes near the Argentine border, at approximately 35.65 S, 70.76 W. It is a remote, sparsely populated area with limited road access. The volcano is the southern component of the Descabezado Grande-Cerro Azul volcanic system within the Southern Andean Volcanic Arc.

faqs.question: What is Quizapu?
faqs.answer: Quizapu is a major volcanic vent (crater) on the northern flank of Cerro Azul. It formed during the volcano's first recorded eruption in 1846 and has been the source of all 11 subsequent eruptions. The Quizapu crater in its current form — 600-700 m wide and 150 m deep — was created by the massive VEI 5 eruption of April 1932. The name is believed to derive from the Mapuche language.

faqs.question: Could the 1932 eruption happen again?
faqs.answer: Yes, a future eruption of similar or greater magnitude is possible at Cerro Azul, though the timing is unpredictable. The volcano's dacitic magma composition is inherently capable of producing large explosive eruptions, as demonstrated in 1932. A repeat event would deposit ash across central Chile and Argentina, disrupting aviation, agriculture, and daily life over a wide area. The volcano's remote location provides a natural buffer against direct casualties, but the far-reaching ashfall would be the primary concern.
